comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: Google Maps has high-resolution aerial imagery of this location, and it looks like the building in the above photo has been replaced.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
"San San Rafael Heights": LOC, can that be right?

Bior, according to the notes from 2011 (at left), the house is still there, but the garden is now different.  The notes also say "Garden Gate", indicating a door in a wall, not a building, but that was left off the main caption.

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Indeed bior, it looks as though the property has been extensively modified.  The author of the text, Gardens for a Beautiful America, Sam Watters adds in his notes: The closed gate, suggesting a hortus conclusus (enclosed garden), was a poetic photography trope, (p. 310). And thank you artolog, for catching the typo, we'll fix that the next time we update the record.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: "Hortus Conclusus", eh?  Well, I'm always on the lookout for a good poetic photography trope~
